results.headline: In Man vs. Wolf Pack, Survival of the Flintiest

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Grey

results.summary_short: Liam Neeson leads a group of men stranded in Alaska after a plane crash in Joe Carnahan’s film “The Grey,” a lean, stripped-down tale of survival in brutal circumstances.

results.headline: Parents Waging a Battle Against the Ultimate Foe

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Declaration of War

results.summary_short: In “Declaration of War,” which carries echoes of the French New Wave, a child’s illness spurs a family to action.

results.headline: Cops and Robbers, and Vertigo

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Man on a Ledge

results.summary_short: In “Man on a Ledge,” an ex-police officer who has been wrongly imprisoned escapes and stalls for time by climbing onto the 21st-floor ledge of a hotel.

results.headline: 14-Year-Old Texan, a Student of Science and Sex

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Five Time Champion

results.summary_short: In “Five Time Champion,” sex and sexual arrangements preoccupy the 14-year-old hero, who has a knack for science.

results.headline: Marveling at a Maestro of Glass, Steel and Light
results.display_title: How Much Does Your Building Weigh, Mr Foster?

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of How Much Does Your Building Weigh, Mr Foster?

results.summary_short: The documentary “How Much Does Your Building Weigh, Mr. Foster?” is an admiring look at the British architect Norman Foster.

results.headline: Long Nap Didn’t Improve Her Mood All That Much

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Underworld: Awakening

results.summary_short: Kate Beckinsale returns as the vampire Selene (now a mother) to fight werewolves in “Underworld: Awakening.”

results.headline: A Case of She Said, She Said and He Can’t Say

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Scalene

results.summary_short: Zack Parker’s “Scalene” is a disturbingly clever drama of triangulated tension among a mother, her mute son and his caregiver.

results.headline: Beauty Queen With No Place to Hide

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Miss Bala

results.summary_short: Gerardo Naranjo’s “Miss Bala,” an art-house thriller, is based on the real story of a Mexican beauty queen who became entangled with a drug cartel.

results.headline: Looking for Halston, Finding the ’70s

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Ultrasuede: In Search of Halston

results.summary_short: Whitney Sudler-Smith’s documentary about Halston demonstrates little interest in fashion and even less insight into that designer.

results.headline: A Renewal of Urban History

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Pruitt-Igoe Myth

results.summary_short: The Pruitt-Igoe Myth” tells the sad story of a public housing project in St. Louis in the broader context of dying American cities after World War II.

results.headline: Someone Done Her Wrong. Horrible Mistake.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Haywire

results.summary_short: “Haywire,” directed by Steven Soderbergh and starring the mixed martial arts fighter Gina Carano, delights in its own action.

results.headline: Pilots Who Fought to Soar Above Racism

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Red Tails

results.summary_short: “Red Tails” is a whiz-bang action film about the Tuskegee Airmen, African-American fighter pilots in World War II.

results.headline: Pick Your Poison: A Bullet or a Virus

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Viral Factor

results.summary_short: Dante Lam’s “Viral Factor” throws a cop with personal problems into a plot involving a smallpox virus.

results.headline: Anime Heroes to the Rescue
results.display_title: Fullmetal Alchemist: The Sacred Star of Milos

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Fullmetal Alchemist: The Sacred Star of Milos

results.summary_short: The Elric brothers of “Fullmetal Alchemist” return to the animated screen to continue their quest for a philosopher’s stone.

results.headline: A Match That Ends at Deuce

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of 16-Love

results.summary_short: In “16-Love,” Lindsey Shaw plays a teenager who finds there’s life (and romance) off the tennis court.

results.headline: Unearthing the Meaning in a Massacre

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Grey Matter

results.summary_short: In “Grey Matter” Kivu Ruhorahoza gathers recollections of the months of massacres in Rwanda and the effects of the bloodshed on those who survived.

results.headline: Recalling When Nighttime Was Dark

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The City Dark

results.summary_short: “The City Dark,” a documentary about light pollution, explores what our increasing inability to see the night sky means for us philosophically as well as scientifically.

results.headline: The Agony Behind an Erotic Club’s Ecstasy

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Crazy Horse

results.summary_short: Frederick Wiseman’s documentary “Crazy Horse” is a behind-the-scenes look at how seriously the famous Paris erotic revue takes itself as an artistic endeavor.

results.headline: Struggle and Song Define a Life

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Sing Your Song

results.summary_short: The years and milestones whoosh by in “Sing Your Song,” a documentary about Harry Belafonte’s big bountiful life as singer, actor and activist.

results.headline: Another Good Reason to Tip Your Super

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Divide

results.summary_short: Residents of a New York apartment building who escape to the basement during a nuclear attack find not sanctuary but a nightmare of mental and physical depravity in “The Divide.”
